author: Joshua
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2017
review_content: Undisputed MVP of my pool equipment team. I have a 3000 gallon Intex 16'x8'x42" Rectangular Prism Frame Pool and a 2100gph Intex Sand Filter. I was vacuuming, filtering, and skimming with my net constantly and still my water was cloudy despite having good numbers all around. There was always a film of dust, and sunscreen sludge on the surface that no amount of filtering or skimming could remove. Swarms of gnats so small that the skim net couldn't retain them would litter the surface. When I mow the lawn, mountains of dust and tiny clippings would settle over the whole pool and the skimmer could do nothing. I'd have to wait for everything to sink and then vacuum. I would cringe when I mowed the lawn. I would cringe when the kids went in with sunscreen on. I would cringe when I saw the gnats swarming in the evenings. And then I bought the Intex Deluxe Wall Mount Surface Skimmer.I was skeptical. It just didn't look all that effective or reliable. When I opened the box, it was bigger than I expected. Installation was incredibly easy and quick. Within half an hour, the surface sludge was gone and before the day was over, my water was sparkling! I'd be remiss if I didn't say that a bit of care and thought goes into using the skimmer effectively. For starters, with my 2100gph pump, I have to install the white restrictor cap over my second outflow port in order to generate enough suction to operate the skimmer. The skimmer works best when blue sleeve floats about 2 to 3 inches above the white base cylinder that the hose attaches to. You get your best performance in calm water. I've left it in while the kids were swimming and it has been fine. But if the water gets too turbulent, you the sleeve could come out or, worse yet, bottom out and you could suck air into your lines. I also have an air leak at my restricted outflow port that causes air to slowly get sucked in to the line. Because of this, I have to shut the pump off for a few seconds every couple of hours to allow the air to escape back up the line. This may not be your experience, but it is something to watch out for.I frequently skim the layer of sludge off of the surface of the skimmer using a name brand paper towel. If you get too much sludge/oil buildup in the skimmer, it will actually float back up out of the skimmer. When I am finished using the skimmer, I detach the hose from the outflow port and I cover the end of the hose with a (you guessed it) name brand paper towel that has been folded in half. I then detach the skimmer and lift it slowly out of the water. The paper towel filters the water as it runs out of the hose and prevents small debris and sludge from flowing out into the pool.I am obsessed with keeping my pool clean and I was fighting a losing battle until I purchased the Intex Deluxe Wall Mount Surface Skimmer. Now I can't wipe the smile off of my face as I watch it devour mountains of bugs and sunscreen sludge.
title: THE best $20 I ever spent. Period.

review_content: Last summer was my 1st year with the pool & I needed to net skim the pool many times per day to keep bugs & debris out. author: Thomas T.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2021
review_content: Don’t expect it to siphon out all debris and make sure your pump exceeds the minimum 800 gal/hr suction. Our 18x9 XT frame pool has two inlets for the pump, and you must install the included reducer cap in one and connect the hose of the strainer to another. There isn’t any good detail on where best to place the device, but the hose limits it to within 2 ft of the inlet you’re using. (If it doesn’t, your suction power will be minimal while the pump is straining, too.)It’s not a magic magnet for all debris, but if the water get stirred up enough during use, it does pretty well over time. Our goal was to capture floating debris before is soaks in and sinks. That it does reasonably well. Of course, it’s something that can be knocked out of alignment during rough play, but it’s sturdy and easy enough to align. Just make sure it’s okay before leaving.

author: Zane H.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 15, 2020
review_content: So worth it. Keeps all the leaves and bugs skimmed off the top of the water. I’ve had no issues with it not working or moving around. author: Lisa B.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 6, 2020
review_content: I normally do not write reviews but this product is so awesome I felt it was worth it!  Many negative reviews for this, not sure why because the product works.  I have a Bestway/Coleman 15x42 steel frame pool.  I have the filter pump which came with it and is mediocre to poor. But it works and until it breaks it is staying.  The Intex skimmer attaches easily to the side of the pool- putting it together and attaching it took 5 minutes. Immediately I noticed it sucking in the floating bugs, leaves, hair and film.  It worked so well that a day later it appeared to stop working.  When I saw that the water from the filter pump exited slowly, I opened up the filter and it was filthy! Cleaned it and the skimmer worked well again!  In two days the same thing happened.  But my pool water is crystal clear and practically bug free!  So what if I have to clean the filter more often.  Not having to skim for 15 minutes every single time the kids go in makes it worth it.  Like others mentioned I blocked off the other intake to make the suction stronger.  And if you are in the pool, take the skimmer off.  It is easy to do, and too much splashing causes all of the gunk collected to seep out.  This will not take the place of vacuuming. author: Jan Schlueter
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2020
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           I have owned and maintained my own above ground swimming pools for over 30 years. Through the years I have had 4 different pools at different homes. The first 2 pools I owned were expensive, high quality pools, and both of these had the typical sidewall mounted skimmer. For my third pool and now fourth pool I decided to save some money by installing the less expensive soft sided type pools. On both of my soft sided pools I have installed these Intex Deluxe Wall Mount Surface Skimmers, and I have been very pleased with the performance of this skimmer. From my own experience, I have found that this Intex wall mount skimmer actually performs better than the typical sidewall mounted type skimmer. With the sidewall skimmer, I usually saw much of the floating debris would float past the skimmer before the skimmer could pull it in. This wall mount skimmer is out in the path of the floating debris and therefore captures the debris more reliably.The instructions clearly state that your pump needs to have at least 800 gallons per hour flow rate for this skimmer to perform correctly. This is not a problem for me because I upgraded to the 14" sand filter which is rated for 2,800 gallons per hour. I have 2 suction hoses on my pool and the skimmer works great even with no restriction on the second hose. If you have 2 suction hoses and a less powerful pump, you will likely need to plug the second hose. This will not cause a problem because the skimmer allows for quite sufficient water flow to the filter.The skimmer kit comes with the fitting and hose to easily connect to the suction fitting. On my pool, I had to remove a small screw from the side of the strainer before I could unscrew it from the pool hose fitting.The only part of this kit I am not completely satisfied with is the mounting clamp. On the plus side, this being the newer model, the clamp does fit the large oval tubing on the newer pool. On the minus side, the plastic clamp is not as rigid as I would prefer, but at this price point I do not expect significantly more. As for longevity; as I stated earlier, I had one of these installed on a previous pool and that one lasted through 4 years of my use and was still usable when I took the pool down and gave it to a friend for their backyard.
title: Performs Better Than A Sidewall Mounted Skimmer

author: Ryan
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 14, 2019
review_content: Meh, it’s alright.  Have had a couple months now. Easy to install. Works better (not great still but better) if you close one of the returns (my pool has 2), but should you really have to do that? Even then, the suction wasn’t ideal. The clasps don’t always hold it in place that well, but it works for the most part. It’s nice the blue part floats with the variation in water height, as we get lots of rain here in Florida. Make sure you clean it out when it’s getting filled, especially if you did have to close one of the returns, because it stops the water flow being the only return. And then put it back after? It’s not hard or anything but can be annoying. It doesn’t catch smaller things so a sock may be beneficial for that. All in all, like I said, it’s ok. I get so much better water flow without it and using BOTH returns that I don’t think it’s worth using. With that, I don’t believe it justifies the money, even if it isn’t too expensive. Also, since it sticks out into the water and is actually bigger than I thought it would be, it catches my floater a lot, which is annoying. I actually think it would be best to get the side wall mounted skimmer. They don’t seem to be too hard to install and you can find them around the same price, as well as getting great reviews. author: Warren Carver
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2017
review_content: I am not compensated by anyone to write my review...This is nice when it's working.  My pool has two vacuum ports, and this takes one of them...It's isn't providing much suction so, it's not the best.  However, when it is working, it's nice to have.  First, I must say I have a 9' x 18' x 52' Intex pool.  It has two suction inlets.Also, just as a top item.  I wish the assembly could better seal so the only way to suck in water was over the blue ring.  The following is a description of that failing to work correctly.In order to get this to work properly, you must restrict the flow of the other.  I have found a custom made plug,  much like the gray one contained in it (only with a few extra holes from leather punch) works best.  HOWEVER, you cannot leave your pool this way, as you will not get proper filtration and will have crap build up at the bottom.  I usually take it off restrictor either each night, or when I think about it and let the pump run normally for a while with no skimmer attached.  You could also just remove the skimmer hose, but it is a giant pain to grab again from outside the pool.It also helps to have this "skimmer" in the back corner.  I thought the middle would work initially but it didn't seem to work as well as the back edge.  I am afraid I might be disturbing the proper circulation though.One MAJOR problem, air in the lines as others have stated.ADDITIONALLY, periodically, the suction will no longer pull the basket down and activate the (blue) float ring to dip letting water flow over it.  So instead it basically pulls water in from under the upper lip, or from the very bottom defeating the purpose of the skimmer.  I really don't care for this design, but with some constant TLC, it will clear the leaves and bugs, etc. from your pool.  My pool is next to an oak tree on one side, and a cherry tree on the other (holy moly, lots of cleaning).  Essentially, I have to use whatever I can get to automate the surface.  I also have to frequently vacuum, but it is worse when the skimmer isn't working.  Today, I clean an nights worth of wind blow debris in about an hour (without manual skimming), but I did have to keep resetting the skimmer, and emptying the basket about every 20 minutes.This bring out another point that many have made.  A good wave or wind, maybe a large bee are all good culprits and blowing the debris in the blue ring all over the pool.  One method I use, take hand leaf skimmer (the oval looking one) and depress the blue ring while skimming the top bit of debris.  That cleans a lot of it without much manipulation.  Depending on quick/accurate I am, it usually fairs well.  For the other times, it takes a bit to catch all the stuff I just dumped back into the pool.The mounting arm is pretty flimsy, and quite annoying.  However, keep in mind it is adjustable for a purpose.  If you have the arm too high, the basket will be very close to the top ring and might create to much suction, which will eventually cause it to stop functioning.  If however, it is too low, the suction will not be strong enough to keep the blue ring below the water (ie situation described above where the water is sucked in below the blue ring), eventually causing it to fail.  It takes a balance, and a lot of attention.  I have taken to ,moving mine so it is angled forcing the front of the blue ring to always be slightly in the water (skimmer moved towards side of pool).  The at least delays the suction issue where the blue ring won't dip below the water.  Not great, but we do what we can.Skimmer socks (smaller cloth based filters that fit over the basket, inside the blue ring) will work great for a short while, but then get filled up with junk and blocks the port.  It also makes it harder for a weak pump.  I've tried them on the inside around just the basket, I've tried them around the entire assembly, which works for a bit.  Ultimately, I think I might have figured out a way to keep them working, but alas, pull them off each time.  The crap off Oak Trees can pass right through some of these wide filters, and reduce the suction on your pump.  If you have a filter style, stop and clean it.  One time mine was nearly clogged in under ten minutes (is in, I just replaced the filter with a new one, started the pump, 10 minutes later I had to pull it out and rinse it off again).  I've also had the sand one need a backwash after a short time for similar reasons.Another note as some have stated.  The blue plastic connector port for the side of the inlet WILL NOT work directly with a vacuum hose.  That was an older connector design (probably around 2014 or earlier) that allowed a vacuum hose to be inserted in to the connector.  Now that same area is covered by a plastic grate to prevent large debris.  Apparently as others have said, the only way to get the correct attachment is the cleaning kit.  I've just ordered one, so I'll review it once I have it.All in all, it's definitely a good thing to have, but it IS NOT set and forget.  Sometimes it works great for a week, sometimes I have to screw with it every 10 minutes.  Most of it has to do with the conditions it's operating in.
title: This is nice when it's working, but it takes a lot of work to (keep) it working.

author: Snmi43
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2020
review_content: Great design and for what you get here. Install is a little tricky, because, well, all Intex directions are never that great. But you knew that already.TIPS FOR EASY SET POOLS:1.  Unless your pump is anything at least 1200gph, don't bother. It's not going to provide enough suction, even when restricting the other port to increase suction in the skimmer.  Even then, I don't think it's doin much.  Even worse, you run those with a small pump,  it DOES somehow fill up and then restricts (and strains) and already weak system.  2k or more gph and this will be the best $20 you spent all summer.2. Keeping the skimmer level. A lot of Easy Set owners complain that it won't remain level because of the design or because it floats or that the inflatable ring is an issue (And yes, these work best on rigid framed pools).  The issue with Easy Set pools is that the tubing is stiff and therefore pushes up on the skimmer, lifting it out of the water.  You can try flexing the hose all you want but you need to RESHAPE THE HOSE.  Use a heat gun on low or a hair dryer to gently warm the tubing. It's cheap hose so you have to go slow,or you'll melt it fast. It doesn't take much.It needs two turns (going from the inlet to the skimmer): One immediate 90 degree right turn out of the inlet nozzle, optimally with a slight downward anfle. Then another 90 degree turn up directly under the skimmer. The rigidity of the hose will assist on keeping it level.  If you don't do this, the hose will always try to straighten, pushing the skimmer around.  No need to over tighten the clamp on the fragile inflatable ring creating a divot by summer's end.  No need to create exterior supports or tie-downs.Hope this helps someone out there!
title: Reshape the hose and it will make your Easy Set even easier.

author: Brian
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 8, 2018
review_content: I have a 9' by 18' metal frame Intex pool.  I'll now be upgrading to a larger pool, but wanted to see how easy or difficult this type of pool was to keep clean before I spent more money.I believe this type of skimmer will work the best with metal framed pools rather than the air filled top rail types.Firstly, I got rid of the factory shipped sand filter and installed a larger one along with a full sized pool pump.  They were easy to find on Amazon (I'm not being paid to post this, just FYI).  The smaller factory pumps just don't have the suction needed to keep a pool clean.  I went to Ace Hardware and got some PVC pipe and fittings and fabricated intake lines to replace the original lines so my modifications would work properly with the new pump.  I would recommend that you use a larger pump than what comes with these larger pools, especially if you plan on using this type of skimmer.  That way, the extra suction will allow the skimmer to work optimally.  While I was at it, I installed another intake line to provide myself with a separate line for vacuuming the pool.  That was easy-I added valves to each intake so I can shut those off and open the vacuum line valve, which only allows the suction through that one line, which provides a greater amount of suction when vacuuming.This skimmer comes with everything needed to install.  Installation was super easy and the shipping was fast.  The only real con I can think of is that the plastic mounting  bracket will eventually lose its firmness (due to sun exposure) and make it difficult to keep in place while people are swimming (due to the splashing/waves) .  When that happens, I remove it from the pool so the basket doesn't come out of the skimmer and release the contents into the pool, or so the seal/ring doesn't sink to the bottom.  However, for the price it's really no big deal to replace every few years.  The only real alternative is to buy a side mount skimmer, but you have to cut the pool liner to install that type of skimmer.  I don't feel super comfortable about doing that and this one works just fine anyway.  I've had my pool for about 4 years and I've only replaced the original once, so not too bad overall.Again, I would recommend buying a more powerful pump and a larger sand filter than what typically comes with these types of pools.  I'm no pool guy, but if you look at the intake and return lines, it's pretty simple to go to your hardware store and buy the pipes and fittings to make your pool efficient at cleaning itself using these larger and more powerful items.  In order to keep your pool clean, though, you must have a skimmer and this one does what it's designed to do.

author: Bonnie
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on August 22, 2017
review_content: Works like a charm. Does exactly what it should. It didn't work well with the 1500gph filter pump, but when I upgraded to the 2500gph, this skimmer delivered. Note: to keep it functioning at peak efficiency, there are a couple maintenance tips you have to do regularly. I noticed the water wasn't swirling in it like it did at first. I shut off the pump, closed the gate valves, and disconnected the hose that goes from the bottom of the skimmer to the outlet on the inside of the pool. Remove the adapter on the outlet, and check the opening. I found a lot of hair caught on the cross bars in the outlet. I removed the hair and reconnected the hose. Next, I disconnected the inlet, or suction hose on the inlet side of the pump. I found more hair on the cross bars of the pump inlet. Cleaned those out, reconnected the inlet hose, removed the filter and hosed it out as well( FYI -  I hose out the filter after every day of heavy use with the garden hose. Been using the same filter for a month). Reinstall filter, open gate valves, purge air from filter housing, and restart pump. I recommend the pump upgrade along with the skimmer to anyone. huge difference in filtering and skimming efficiency. I have an 18' x 48" Ultra Set pool.

author: Alison
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2017
review_content: Lets set expectations - I've never owned a pool (other than blow up pool for infants) I didn't know what I was doing when I purchased a large "easy set" pool from intex.  I had bought my summer "throw away pool" when I saw a deal I couldn't pass up on an intex 12 x 20 "blow-up" pool.  I rolled the dice with little understanding of what I was getting into.  1st recommendation was "make sure you have level ground, hire a pro"  I found the most level area of my large yard, via eyeballing it, and filled it up - turns out it was 1/4 to 1/2 off from end to end.  Acceptable.  I upgraded the filter, because how could you ignore the enormous amount of folks bitching about the included cartridge filters?  That being said, I have learned pools are a learning process and......work.  I was skimming the pool every morning and every time that the girls were getting in it (we've had it 10 days) I purchased this, and installed it 3 hours ago.  I have watched all of the gross stuff that I was skimming quickly disappear.  Here is the key (if you have the blow up sort of pool) the floating skimmer is a pretty cool design - the best skimming is if the unit is level to the water.  If you read the instruction it recommends that the basket is 1 - 5 inches below the surface.  I found that 3-5 inches is best as the float needs room to level itself.  on the blow up pools the side doesn't keep it that level so the deeper the mechanism is the more room the floating part has to level itself (I hope that makes sense) then adjust the suction tubes as to not be putting pressure on the unit that "cocks" it sideways.  If you try to get the unit as level as possible and then drop the basket to the max depth - it works like a charm.  My kids were complaining that I was always working rather than playing and now I feel like I have a handle on it.  I'm buying the saltwater conversion next - preparing the chemical cocktail that this thing needs is a joke (no fault of the pool - just chemistry) sounds like the saltwater is a no-brainer.  I have spent 85 in chemicals in the first 10 days.
title: Buy it if you have an easy-set pool (blow-up)

review_content: Just installed this today on my Intex 10'x30" pool. The pool is used mostly for the dog to jump in once she comes out of the gulf. author: Adam D Millsap
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 6, 2013
review_content: Our pool in under a thick tree canopy. All summer I either spent and hour a day skimming, and an hour a week vacuuming, or I dealt with gross leaves on the bottom of the pool.This skimmer was the solution. I was very pleased with the quality, design and function. Heres what I've learned about making it work.1. Make sure you get it relatively level.2. Set the level of the lower housing so the float does not lift the sealing ring. This is critical because if the sealing ring is lifted off the lower housing, debris will bypass the basket and clogs will decrease or stop system flow.3. If you are using this skimmer with a pool that has an inflatable ring around the top keep your water level at the bottom of the ring. Other wise you cannot adjust the lower house up high enough, and the sealing ring will be lifted.4.Stop the water flow before you remove the basket for emptying, or you will end up with clogs.Good luck. I love this thing.

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2012
review_content: My first impression after opening the box was one of "How can this cheesy looking arrangement of plastic parts actually be effective as a skimmer?" The only thing I don't like is cleaning out the accumulated scum.  Not done right and it all goes back into the pool.  I finally realized that if I lifted the entire bottom portion (unhooking it from the pool rim), the filter pump will suck all of the scum out of the skimmer and you're left with just the stuff trapped by the basket.  Time will tell how durable it will be when exposed to daily doses of UV light.  A worthwhile purchase for an Intex pool.
